awd_titl_txt: CAREER:  Global analysis of in vivo protein folding efficiencies by mass spectrometry
awd_abstract_narration:
Proteins are initially synthesized as linear polymers and must subsequently fold into precise three-dimensional structures. Within a cell, this folding reaction is often error prone and can lead to misfolded and nonfunctional proteins. The cell contains a number of quality control mechanisms for degrading misfolded and nonfunctional proteins. In this project, Dr. Ghaemmaghami?s laboratory will develop a novel technique for measuring the fraction of proteins that successfully fold within the cell after synthesis. Using this technique, Dr. Ghaemmaghami will study variations in the folding efficiencies of several proteins. The results will elucidate relationships between physical properties of proteins and their propensity to fold successfully within a cell. On the whole, this research will establish novel techniques that will facilitate investigations of protein folding inside cells and lead to a greater understanding of factors that influence protein homeostasis.

Broader impacts. Integrated educational activities of the proposal include creating an interactive, web-based teaching module that introduces students and the public to theoretical and practical aspects of modern proteomics. Additionally, a number of research opportunities will be provided to high school and undergraduate students. The multidisciplinary nature of the project (encompassing protein biochemistry, cell biology, analytical chemistry, physical chemistry and quantitative biology) will provide cross-departmental research opportunities to graduate students. The research will lead to the development of mass spectrometry related protocols and novel analysis software and will facilitate proteomic research at the University of Rochester. It will also provide a foundation for cross-departmental collaborative research. The software will be made freely available to the research community and could be widely used by researchers interested in dynamic proteomics.
org_div_long_name: Division of Molecular and Cellular Biosciences

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp

por.por_cntn:
Proteins are the main functional units of life and carry out most of the activities that are required for maintaining a living organism. Proteins are initially synthesized as linear polymers and must subsequently fold into precise three-dimensional structures. Within a cell, this folding reaction is often error prone and can lead to the production of misfolded and nonfunctional proteins. The cell contains a number of quality control mechanisms for degradation of these misfolded and nonfunctional proteins. In this project, we developed a number of novel tools that allow us to assess the proper folding of proteins and their degradation within cells. Importantly, by using an analytical approach named liquid chromatography tandem mass spectrometry (LC-MS/MS), we have been able to analyze protein folding stability and degradation for thousands of proteins at once, providing a global assessment of the functionality of the protein pool within a cell.

Our results indicate that within a cell, different proteins are degraded at widely different rates and their half-lives range from minutes to years. We have shown that protein half-lives are established by a complex combination of factors including the folding state of the protein and activities of different degradation mechanisms in the cell. Protein half-lives not only vary between proteins, but also can vary for the same protein expressed in different organisms, tissues, cell types and environmental conditions. Our protein folding data have identified specific classes of proteins within a cell that have particularly high or low stabilities. For example, we have shown that proteins that are expressed in lysosomes (the major degradative organelle in eukaryotic cells) and are present outside the cell have particularly high stabilities. We also showed that the folding stability of proteins impacts their tendency to become oxidized, and have identified subsets of proteins that are particularly prone to this form of damage. Together, our data have provided a census of the folding stabilities and half-lives of proteins within human cells and have developed methodologies that can be used to assess these properties for thousands of proteins under different environmental conditions. On the whole, this research has led to a greater understanding of factors that influence the proper functioning of proteins within cells.

The project was the basis of one Masters project and five Ph.D. projects for graduate students at the University of Rochester. Other educational goals of the proposal included the creation of an interactive, web-based teaching module that introduces students and the public to theoretical and practical aspects of LC-MS/MS. This module was implemented in a number of undergraduate courses at the University of Rochester.  Additionally, a number of research opportunities were provided to high school and undergraduate students. Community outreach activities included the Upward Bound program and Ronald E. McNair Post-baccalaureate Achievement program that provides low-income, first-generation college students and underrepresented minorities opportunities to participate in mentored research projects. As part of our outreach activities, the PI served as a science mentor in East High School, an inner-city school in Rochester, NY. The project involved in the design of and implementation of an experiment for the Student Spaceflight Experiments Program (SSEP) offered by NASA. This program allows high school students to design and propose real experiments to fly in low earth orbit on the International Space Station. The project proposed by East High School was one of 21 projects across the United States and Canada that was selected to be on board SSEP Mission 10 that was launched on June 2017.

 


Last Modified: 04/29/2020
Modified by: Sina Ghaemmaghami
